title: Timeline of the Richard Nixon presidency
deleted: * '''January 1''' – President Nixon spends [[New Year's Day]] at [[Camp David]] with his family and aides.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1971/01/02/page/11/article/nixon-watches-tv-bowl-games-and-signs-66-bills|title=Nixon Watches TV Bowl Games and Signs 66 Bills|date=January 2, 1971|publisher=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>

* '''January 2''' – The White House releases the text of a message sent to Congress by President Nixon the previous day alongside his vetoing of a bill raising the pay for roughly 850,000 federal workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1971/01/03/page/1/article/display-ad-128-no-title|title=Major Battles Put Off; Pay Raise Vetoed|date=January 3, 1971|publisher=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>
* '''January 22''' – President Nixon delivers the 1971 State of the Union Address to a joint session of Congress.{{citation needed|date=March 2021}}
* '''February 16''' – Secret Service Agents install the White House Taping system. Its operation will be refined over the months to improve its reception.

* '''March 24''' – In a 51-46 vote, the Senate cuts off government funding for the Nixon-supported supersonic transport airplane.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1971/03/25/page/1/article/a-defeat-for-nixon|title=A Defeat for Nixon|date=March 24, 1971|publisher=Chicago Tribune|first=Philip|last=Warden}}</ref>

* '''June 13''' – ''The New York Times'' begins publishing excerpts from the [[Pentagon Papers]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.history.com/topics/vietnam-war/pentagon-papers|title=Pentagon Papers – Vietnam War |website=History.com|access-date=2017-02-04}}</ref>

* '''July 15''' – President Nixon announces that he had been invited to visit China.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/nixon-announces-trip-to-china|title=Nixon announces trip to China – Jul 15, 1971 |newspaper=History.com|access-date=2017-02-04}}</ref>

* '''November 3''' – Secretary of Defense Laird meets with top American officials based in [[Saigon]] on intentions to send thousands of GIs back to the US during the holiday season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711104&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Laird Meets With U.S. Officials In Saigon|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=November 4, 1971}}</ref>

* '''November 8''' – The White House states its interest in the imposition of revisions made to a water pollution control bill sponsored by Senator [[Edmund Muskie]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711109&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Nixon Administration Reportedly Seeks Revision In Water|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=November 9, 1971}}</ref>

* '''November 16''' – Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare Richardson discloses that the Nixon administration is looking into reforming the Social Security accounting system.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711117&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=White House Eyes Social Security System Revision|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=November 17, 1971}}</ref> The Senate votes 53 to 29 in favor of President Nixon having the authority to impose a 15% surcharge on imports into the US.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711117&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Senate Votes To Grant Nixon Import Authority|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=November 17, 1971}}</ref> Secretary of the Treasury Connally lauds the wage-price increase as successful and foresees post-freeze controls cutting inflation in half during the following year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711117&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Connally Calls Freeze A Resounding Success|date=November 17, 1951|publisher=Herald-Journal}}</ref>

* '''December 2''' – [[Earl Butz]] is sworn in as the 18th [[United States Secretary of Agriculture]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711203&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Senate Confirms Butz's Nomination|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=December 3, 1971}}</ref>

* '''December 9''' – President Nixon vetoes a federal childcare program that he charges as too costly and unworkable.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711210&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=President Vetoes Child-Care Program|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=December 10, 1971}}</ref> Congress sends a tax cut bill to President Nixon reducing the taxes on individuals and businesses by US$15.8 billion during the night.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711210&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Congress Passes Tax Cut Bill, Sends It to Nixon|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=December 10, 1971}}</ref>

* '''December 10''' – President Nixon signs a tax bill, cutting consumer and business taxes by 15.8 billion over the following three years, into law.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711211&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|title=Nixon Signs Tax Bill Into Law|publisher=Herald-Journal|date=December 11, 1971}}</ref> [[William Rehnquist]] is confirmed to the United States Supreme Court by a Senate vote of 68 to 26.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711211&printsec=frontpage&hl=en Rehnquist Wins Senate Approval (December 11, 1971)]</ref>

* '''December 11''' – [[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense]] [[David Packard]] resigns.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711212&printsec=frontpage&hl=en Packard Resigns Post As Deputy Secretary of Defense (December 12, 1971)]</ref>

* '''December 12''' – Secretary of State Rogers said continued lack of action by the [[United Nations]] on the India-Pakistan War would portray the UN as ineffective while speaking to reporters.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=SFOYbPikdlgC&dat=19711213&printsec=frontpage&hl=en U.N. Would Be Branded 'Failure' Explains Rogers (December 13, 1971)]</ref>
